facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 281 of 1962 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 281 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 14, 1959 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 2145 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 14, 1959 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 2145 of 1958.

facts.text: Respondents numbers 1 to 11 were the Jagirdars of Waghach State in former Sankeda Mewar in Reva Kantha Agency which now forms part of the State of Gujarat.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents number. 1 to I 1 were the Jagirdars of Waghach State in former Sankeda Mewar in Reva Kantha Agency which number forms part of the State of Gujarat.

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 11 claimed they were full owners of all land including forest areas and exercised full revenue power during their regime.

anchor.surface_text: They claimed that they were the full owners of all the land including forest areas in the said State and exercised full revenue power during their regime.

facts.text: There were 39 villages in Waghach State all of which had forests. Except for cultivated lands, all lands were forest lands.

anchor.surface_text: There were 39 villages in Waghach State in all of which there were forests. Except for the lands which were cultivated, all the lands in the said villages were forest lands.

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 11 claimed full proprietary rights over forest lands and enjoyed produce as full owners.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents number. 1 to l1 further claimed that they had full proprietary rights over the forest lands and enjoyed the produce as full owners thereof.

facts.text: By agreement of merger dated June 1, 1948, Waghach State merged with Bombay effective June 10, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: By the agreement of merger dated June 1, 1948 the State of Waghach was merged with the State of Bombay with effect from June 10, 1948.

facts.text: On August 19, 1953, respondents 1 to 11 entered agreement with respondent 12 entitling 12 to cut and remove all tree species from forests in 39 villages for 10 years.

anchor.surface_text: On August 19, 1953, respondents 1 to 11 entered into an agreement with respondent number 12 whereby respondent number 12 became entitled to cut and remove all species of trees from the forest lands in the 39 villages for a period of ten years.

facts.text: Bombay Merged Territories and Areas Jagirs Abolition Act, 1953 (Act XXXIX of 1954) came into force on August 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1954, the Bombay Merged Territories and Areas  Jagirs Abolition  Act, 1953  Act XXXIX of 1954  came into force.

facts.text: The jagirs were undisputedly proprietary jagirs under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is the undisputed position in the present case that the jagirs fell in the category of proprietary jagirs.

facts.text: Under s.5 of Jagirs Abolition Act, Jagirdars became occupants of lands including forest areas in their possession before the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 5 of the Jagirs Abolition Act the Jagirdars became occupants in the lands including forest areas which were in their possession before companying into force of the Act.

facts.text: On July 6, 1956, State Government issued notification under s.34A Indian Forest Act declaring uncultivated lands in 39 villages as forests for Ch.5.

anchor.surface_text: On July 6, 1956 the State Government issued a numberification under s. 34 A  of the Indian Forest Act. declaring all uncultivated lands in the said 39 villages to be forests for the purposes of Ch. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: On March 19, 1958, Divisional Forest Officer wrote to respondents that jagirdars' rights abolished by Act, reserved trees belong to State, refrain from cutting teak and Pancharao.

anchor.surface_text: On March 19, 1953 the Divisional Forest Officer wrote a letter to the respondents wherein he stated that all the rights of the jagirdars had been abolished by the Jagirs Abolition Act and that the reserved species of trees standing on the lands belonged to the State Government.

facts.text: On July 11, 1958, Divisional Forest Officer wrote that reserved trees (teak, blackwood, sandalwood) vested in State, prohibited cutting.

anchor.surface_text: On July 11, 1958. the Divisional Forest Officer wrote another letter to the respondents in which he stated that the reserved species of trees--teak, blackwood and sandalwood--vested in the State Government and, therefore, prohibited the respondents from cutting and removing the material from those trees.

facts.text: On July 11, 1958, Divisional Forest Officer informed respondents that cut teak and blackwood material in forests advertised for sale.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date he wrote another letter to the respondents and informed them that the material obtained by cutting teak and blackwood trees which was tying in the forest lands, had been advertised for sale.

facts.text: Respondents filed Special Civil Application No. 2146 of 1958 in Bombay High Court for mandamus to cancel letters dated March 19, 1958 and July 11, 1958 and restrain appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents thereafter filed a Special Civil Application number 2146 of 1958 in the High Court of Judicature at Bombay against the applicants for the grant of a writ in the nature of mandamus under Art. 226 of the Constitution directing them to cancel the orders companytained in the fetters of the Divisional Forest Officer dated March 19, 1958 and July 11, 1958 and to restrain the appellants from enforcing the said orders.

facts.text: Bombay High Court by judgment dated January 14, 1959 allowed the application, held jagirdars became occupants entitled to trees, issued injunction restraining State from preventing cutting.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by its judgment dated January 14, 1959, allowed the application of the respondents holding that after companying into force of the Jagirs Abolition Act the rights of the jagirdars in the forest lands and the trees were extinguished but at the same time jagirdars became occupants of the forest lands under s. 5 1  b  of the said Act and they accordingly became entitled to the trees standing on the forest lands.

facts.text: Appeal brought by special leave by State of Gujarat and other appellants against High Court order in Special Civil Application No. 2146 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is brought by special leave on behalf of the State of Gujarat and the other appellants against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in the Special Civil Application number 2146 of 1958.

facts.text: The 36 villages in question have not been surveyed or settled.

anchor.surface_text: the 36 villages in dispute have number been surveyed or settled and until there is companypletion of the survey and settlement there is numberquestion of companycession on the part of the State Government of the right to the trees in favour of the occupants.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that occupants' rights under Bombay Land Revenue Code do not include right to cut and remove trees from forest lands absent survey settlement.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the rights of the occupants under the Bombay Land Revenue Code do number include the right to cut and remove the trees from the forest lands. The reason is that the 36 villages in dispute have number been surveyed or settled

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order dated January 14, 1959, dismissed Special Civil Application.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the order of the High Court dated January 14, 1959 in Special Civil Application number 2146 of 1958 and order that the Special Civil Application should be dismissed.

facts.text: Trees standing in forest lands of 39 villages belong to State Government, not to jagirdars respondents 1 to 11.

anchor.surface_text: The question presented for determination in this case is whether the trees standing in the forest lands of the 39 villages in question belong to the jagirdars--respondents 1 to 11 or to the State Government

anchor.surface_text: Our view is supported by the language of s. 10 of the Jagirs Abolition Act which expressly saves the right of the jagirdar to mines or mineral products in a jagir village subsisting on the appointed day. There is no provision in the Jagirs Abolition Act corresponding to s. 10 with regard to the saving of the right to the trees in favour of the jagirdars.

holdings.text: Under s. 3 of the Jagirs Abolition Act all jagirs were abolished and all the rights of the jagirdars were extinguished, save those rights which are expressly provided by other provisions of the Act itself.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the view expressed by the High Court is erroneous and must be reversed. It is manifest that under s. 3 of the Jagirs Abolition Act all jagirs were abolished and all the rights of the jagirdars were extinguished, save those rights which are expressly provided by other provisions of the Act itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 3 expressly abolishes jagirs and extinguishes all jagirdar rights unless saved by other provisions; no general saving for tree rights.

holdings.text: Under s. 5(1)(b) of the Jagirs Abolition Act the only rights conferred on the jagirdars are the rights of occupancy of the forest lands.

anchor.surface_text: It is also manifest that under s. 5 1 b of the Act the only rights conferred on the jagirdars are the rights of occupancy of the forest lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5(1)(b) makes jagirdars occupants entitled to occupant rights and liabilities under Bombay Land Revenue Code, but no more.

holdings.text: The rights of the occupants under the Bombay Land Revenue Code do not include the right to cut and remove the trees from the forest lands.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the rights of the occupants under the Bombay Land Revenue Code do not include the right to cut and remove the trees from the forest lands. The reason is that the 36 villages in dispute have not been surveyed or settled

holdings.reasoning_summary: Occupancy rights defined in BLRC; s.40 requires survey settlement for cession of tree rights to occupants.

holdings.text: Until there is completion of the survey and settlement there is no question of cession on the part of the State Government of the right to the trees in favour of the occupants.

anchor.surface_text: and until there is completion of the survey and settlement there is no question of cession on the part of the State Government of the right to the trees in favour of the occupants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.40 BLRC provides for deemed cession of tree rights only upon completion of survey settlement; villages not settled.

holdings.text: Section 9 of the Jagirs Abolition Act is not an express provision saving the right of the jagirdars with regard to the trees.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, s. 9 of the jagirs Abolition Act is not an express provision saving the right of the jagirdars with regard to the trees and the argument of Mr. Desai must be rejected on this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 extinguishes rights unless expressly saved; s.9 vests reserved tree rights in State, does not save for jagirdars.

holdings.text: There is no provision in the Jagirs Abolition Act corresponding to s. 10 with regard to the saving of the right to the trees in favour of the jagirdars.

anchor.surface_text: Our view is supported by the language of s. 10 of the Jagirs Abolition Act which expressly saves the right of the jagirdar to mines or mineral products in a jagir village subsisting on the appointed day. There is no provision in the Jagirs Abolition Act corresponding to s. 10 with regard to the saving of the right to the trees in favour of the jagirdars.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10 expressly saves mine rights contrasting with absence for trees, confirming no saving under s.3.

holdings.text: After coming into force of the Jagirs Abolition Act respondents 1 to 11 became occupants in respect of the forest lands in the 36 villages and the only rights which they have are those of occupants under the provisions of the Bombay Land Revenue Code and such rights do not include the right to cut and remove the trees from the forest lands of the villages in question.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that after coming into force of the Jagirs Abolition Act respondents 1 to 11 became occupants in respect of the forest lands in the 36 villages and the only rights which they have are those of occupants under the provisions of the Bombay Land Revenue Code and such rights do not include the right to cut and remove the trees from the forest lands of the villages in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis of ss.3,5 Jagirs Act and BLRC ss.40,41; no tree rights without cession via settlement; reserved trees vest in State.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in holding that the respondents were entitled to cut and remove all species of trees standing in the forest lands of the 36 villages in question.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was in error in holding that the respondents were entitled to cut and remove all species of trees standing in the forest lands of the 36 villages in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's interpretation of occupant rights erroneous per above analysis of statutes.

edges.explanation: The holding on rights under the Bombay Land Revenue Code is grounded in the provisions of Section 3(16) as cited in the concept node.
The holding interprets and is grounded in the definition or provisions of Section 3(17), Bombay Land Revenue Code regarding occupants' rights.
Section 3(17) addresses the legal question of what rights occupants have under the Code, including whether cutting trees is included.
The holding on rights under the Bombay Land Revenue Code is grounded in Section 3(19) as the relevant provision defining such rights.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the view expressed by the High Court is erroneous and must be reversed. It is manifest that under s. 3 of the Jagirs Abolition Act all jagirs were abolished and all the rights of the jagirdars were extinguished, save those rights which are expressly provided by other provisions of the Act itself.
We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the order of the High Court dated January 14, 1959 in Special Civil Application number 2146 of 1958 and order that the Special Civil Application should be

edges.explanation: h2 limiting to occupancy rights supports h3 that such rights exclude cutting trees

anchor.surface_text: It is also manifest that under s. 5 1 b of the Act the only rights conferred on the jagirdars are the rights of occupancy of the forest lands.
We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the order of the High Court dated January 14, 1959 in Special Civil Application number 2146 of 1958 and order that the Special Civil Application should be

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, s. 9 of the jagirs Abolition Act is not an express provision saving the right of the jagirdars with regard to the trees and the argument of Mr. Desai must be rejected on this point.
We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the order of the High Court dated January 14, 1959 in Special Civil Application number 2146 of 1958 and order that the Special Civil Application should be

edges.explanation: Holding of no s.10-equivalent saving for trees addresses issue of implied tree rights

anchor.surface_text: Our view is supported by the language of s. 10 of the Jagirs Abolition Act which expressly saves the right of the jagirdar to mines or mineral products in a jagir village subsisting on the appointed day. There is no provision in the Jagirs Abolition Act corresponding to s. 10 with regard to the saving of the right to the trees in favour of the jagirdars.
We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the order of the High Court dated January 14, 1959 in Special Civil Application number 2146 of 1958 and order that the Special Civil Application should be
ompanying into force of the Jagirs Abolition Act respondents 1 to 11 became occupants in respect of the forest lands in the 36 villages and the only r

edges.explanation: h7 on occupants having only occupancy rights post-Act addresses tree ownership in forests

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that after coming into force of the Jagirs Abolition Act respondents 1 to 11 became occupants in respect of the forest lands in the 36 villages and the only rights which they have are those of occupants under the provisions of the Bombay Land Revenue Code and such rights do not include the right to cut and remove the trees from the forest lands of the villages in question.
We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the order of the High Court dated January 14, 1959 in Special Civil Application number 2146 of 1958 and order that the Special Civil Application should be
We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the order of the High Court dated January 14, 1959 in Special Civil Application number 2146 of 1958 and order that the Special Civil Application should be
